Description.val:
The MQ-8 Unmanned Air System (popular name "Fire Scout") provides real-time and non-real-time Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) data to tactical users without the use of manned aircraft or reliance on limited joint theater or national assets. This line item funds improvements via engineering change orders, correction of deficiencies, obsolescence and safety.  This includes items such as modernization, modification of payloads/mission systems/Mission Control System (MCS) (also referred to as Ground Control Station), and retrofit of systems/avionics.  The program will procure a total of 63 air vehicles (30 MQ-8Bs (6 lost to attrition) and 33 MQ-8Cs) to support Fleet requirements. Current inventory is twenty-four (24) MQ-8B and nineteen (19) MQ-8C air vehicles. Twenty-four (24) MQ-8B Fire Scout systems are in service, of which twenty-two (22) are available for fleet use.  Nineteen (19) MQ-8C Fire Scouts are in service with fourteen (14) additional MQ-8Cs under contract.  Twenty-two (22) MQ-8Bs and fourteen (14) MQ-8Cs are located at the Contractor Field Team (CFT) facility at Pt Mugu, CA, two (2) MQ-8B and five (5) MQ-8C Fire Scouts at Webster Field, MD.  These Operational, Safety and Improvement Programs align to the MQ-8B Initial Operational Capability in 2014 and MQ-8C deliveries that commenced in 2015. 

The MQ-8 Fire Scout system includes air vehicle(s), payloads (i.e., electro-optical/infra-red/laser designator-range finder, Automated Information System (AIS), voice communications relay, Radar, Weapons and other specialty payloads), MCS (with Tactical Control System and Tactical Common Data Link integrated for interoperability), Unmanned Air Vehicle Common Automatic Recovery System (UCARS) for automatic launch and recovery, training systems, associated spares, and support equipment.  The quantities and schedules for MCS and UCARS components are based on host ship requirements, while quantities and schedules for air vehicle components are based on operational deployment plans.  The MQ-8 system supports Littoral Combat Ship and/or suitably-equipped air capable ship ISR collection for Navy and urgent operational requirements.  Designated service life and average service life remaining are currently being computed via a fatigue life evaluation.  All air vehicles support the active military component.

Justification.val: FY19 funds improvements via engineering change orders, for correction of deficiencies, obsolescence and safety. This includes correction of deficiencies found during operational use and deployments, improvements for maintainability and reliability, safety corrections, Radar/other special payloads, Mission Control System (MCS), and emerging requirements and retrofit of capabilities procured post air vehicle delivery.  Budget reflects MQ-8Cs, procurements starting in FY12, being transitioned to fleet service.

ModificationTitle.val: MQ-8 Correction of Deficiencies and Modernization (OSIP 021-14)

Name.@footnote: Due to the number of ECPs starting and stopping between FY17 to FY23, the Support cost elements (ILS, Data, Training Equipment, Support Equipment, and Other Support) cannot be analyzed at standard phasing levels.

FY17 Trainer requirement of $1.45M (PB17) shifted to FY18 to align with planned contract award for MQ-8B/C trainer equipment capability improvements.  FY18 Training increase supports update of the Avionics Maintenance Trainer (AMT) and Combined Maintenance Trainer (CMT) training devices to ensure provided training aligns with the same configuration of fleet air vehicles.  FY19-FY23 training increases support trainer devices and maintenance course capability improvements for the AMT and CMT and various proficiency training device improvement and associated courseware.

Title.val: MQ-8 Correction of Deficiencies and Modernization (OSIP 021-14)

Where possible, the program will accelerate out-year maintainability and reliability, and safety related ECPs.

Description.val:
This Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) provides resources to correct MQ-8 Air Vehicle deficiencies resulting from readiness, obsolescence, safety and Diminishing Manufacturing Sources and Material Shortages (DMSMS) issues. It also provides for Pre-Planned Product Improvement (P3I) efforts that will improve and modernize system performance, reliability, and maintainability of sensors, avionics, and airframe components to support Intelligence, Surveillance, and Reconnaissance collection for both Navy and urgent operational requirements. In order to meet emerging deficiencies in the MQ-8B and MQ-8C aircraft, integrated systems and trainers must be modified as critical corrections / changes are identified.  Funds will be used to incorporate Engineering Change Proposals (ECP) and implement those changes to sustain and improve operations.  

Modifications for the MQ-8 aircraft include, but are not limited to: the Identification Friend or Foe system, avionics bay redesign, MQ-8B Radar, VORTEX relocation, Automatic Identification System, hot weather modifications, blades, engines, control rods, heavy gauge wiring, engine accelerometers, optical tracker cable, navigation lights, corrosion prevention, light weight doors, Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Common Automated Recovery System (UCARS), lithium battery, MQ-8 windscreen, MQ-8 airframe structure, MQ-8 pitot tubes, ARC-210 radios, Tactical Common Data Link, shipboard interface system, MQ-8 common avionics, software, cyber security, network interfaces, processor upgrades, System Integration Lab (SIL) and Hardware-in-the-Loop (HITL) enhancements, Windows 10 transition, maintenance device updates, and other related systems. 

The FY19 budget focus includes dual UCARS, the top safety priority for the MQ-8, and MQ-8B radar, an essential warfighter capability requested by the fleet.   

This OSIP provides funds to support modifications to address safety and readiness issues and will be depot-level, performed by Fleet Readiness Centers, contractor artisans, contractor field modification teams, and/or organic support and the establishment of Organic Depot Capability for Core Repairables.  Coincident with the MQ-8B deployment on the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) class, a top ten safety issue list was developed during the program's System Safety Working Group. As solutions become available, aircraft modifications will be implemented to address critical safety issues. Identified issues may include icing detection/avoidance, ground handling, airspace awareness, Global Positioning System vulnerabilities, and cyber security.

Mission Control System (MCS), UCARS, and Payloads requirements were aligned from OSIP 021-14 to OSIPs 009-17 and 010-17, respectively in PB17.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: MQ-8B Initial Operational Capability (IOC) occurred in FY14. The MQ-8B has deployed since FY10 to support Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance Task Force, Joint Urgent Operational Need, and is embarked in the second operational deployment aboard the LCS class as part of the Surface Warfare Mission Package.

ModificationTitle.val: MQ-8 Mission Control System (MCS) Readiness, Obsolescence and Safety (OSIP 009-17)

Description.val:
This Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) addresses modifications to the Mission Control System (MCS) for hardware and software obsolescence.  Increases are because the External Communications (EXCOMM) rack and the Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Common Automatic Recovery System (UCARS) have obsolete components which require replacement.  Some non-recurring engineering has been completed to support production.  This effort procures the kits required and funds the retrofit of shipboard MD-4 MCS equipment onboard Littoral Combat Ships (LCS) and shore-based MD-4 MCS equipment installed at Point Mugu, CA.  

This budget accelerates MCS Upgrades to reduce cyber security vulnerabilities, reduces obsolescence, and supports fleet requirements.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  MQ-8B Initial Operational Capability (IOC) occurred in FY14.  The MQ-8B has deployed since FY10 to support Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) Task Force, Joint Urgent Operational Need, and is embarked in the second operational deployment aboard the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) class as part of the Surface Warfare Mission Package.  

MCS and UCARS requirements were aligned from OSIP 021-14 to OSIP 009-17 in PB17.

Name.@footnote: FY17 training requirements were consolidated to FY18 to support Radar A-kit cost updates and to align with availability of engineering data for trainer capability improvements.    FY18-FY20 training increases support trainer device and maintenance course updates for Radar and Weapons capability improvements.

The Radar A-Kit cost for FY19-FY22 was revised to align with proposed A-Kit costs from the Prime RADAR Integration Phase II proposal (contract in negotiations). The A-Kit cost increased due to the addition of Minotaur hardware to the A-Kit.
Name.val: 1.1.1) MQ-8C Radar Upgrade II A Kits - NonOrganic
2.1.1) MQ-8C Radar Upgrade II B Kits - Organic

Name.@footnote: To align with Department priorities, the APKWS Weapons program start was deferred beyond the FYDP.  NRE for an initial APKWS Weapons payload integration and installation procedures was added in FY23.  Previously budgeted APKWS resources were realigned to MQ-8C radar efforts to support Fleet requirement to accelerate installations.
Non-recurring provides for engineering installation procedures for incorporating payloads into fielded air vehicles.

Description.val:
The MQ-8 Payloads Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) addresses modifications to the MQ-8 Fire Scout System which add new payloads, such as Radar and the Advanced Precision Kill Weapons System (APKWS) II, and add capability and reliability improvements to existing payloads.  

The Radar payload includes the integration of a competitively-selected non-developmental item Radar with the air vehicle, Minotaur data correlation and resource management software and hardware, and Mission Control Station (MCS).  This capability will improve the MQ-8 Fire Scout's performance in support of Surface Warfare (SUW) Mission Module for the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) and urgent operational requirements.  Once the hardware and software modifications to the air vehicle and MCS are complete, the MQ-8 Fire Scout Mission System Trainer, Avionics Technicians' Trainer, and Aircraft Mechanics' Trainer will be upgraded to include this capability.  Delivered MQ-8C air vehicles will be retrofitted for the upgrades via kits.

There will be future integration of a weapons payload to include transition of the MQ-8B weaponization Rapid Deployment Capability (RDC) hardware and software to the MQ-8C air vehicle.  Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE) for initial payloads weapons design and integration study will commence in FY23 for the APKWS II missile and its associated hardware and software modifications to the MQ-8C air vehicle and MCS.  NRE to integrate and qualify existing Bell 407 external stores suspension equipment with the MQ-8C Air Vehicle (AV) and retrofit of delivered MQ-8C AVs with Weapons payload upgrades via kits are deferred beyond the FYDP.

There will be future integration of payloads in support of the Mine Countermeasures (MCM) mission module on LCS.  Future payloads include the Coastal Battlefield Reconnaissance and Analysis (COBRA) system and the Data Mission Payload (DMP).  Future payload integration efforts will be considered when integrating current efforts.  
Payload requirements were aligned from OSIP 021-14 in PB16 to OSIP 010-17 in PB17.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS AND MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: 
Payload Milestones:  A maritime Radar has been competitively selected for integration into the MQ-8C Fire Scout System.  Completion of development and integration is anticipated in FY18 with a Follow-on Test and Evaluation (FOT&E) period starting in 2Q FY19, followed by an Initial Operational Capability (IOC) in 4Q FY20.

MQ-8 System Milestones:  MQ-8B IOC occurred in FY14.  The MQ-8B has deployed since FY10 to support Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) Task Force, Joint Urgent Operational Need requirements, and has embarked in the second operational deployment aboard the LCS class as part of the SUW Mission Package.
